docs.text:
Welcome to the Cyber Reference Wiki
#


Sections
#


Hunt
 - Blue/Hunt-related sites


Tools
 - Tools of the trade


Intel
 - All things Intel


How To
 - In-depth walkthroughs and tutorials


References
 - Generic IT references to learn the basics


Exercises
 - Exercises and challenges to hone your craft


Red Team
 - Evil shenanigans

docs.text:
Purpose
#


"Hunt" or "Blue" topics include all things related to defense against the dark arts, at least within the cyber discipline.  


Links
#


ROCK NSM Project


Synopsis:
 The MOCYBER open source NSM sensor.


DavidJBianco/ThreatHunting


Synopsis:
 Repo containing synopsis of several hunting techniques


Intro to DFIR, by @sroberts


Synopsis:
 Overview of topics related to DFIR. Each topic has links to
videos, references, tools and key experts to follow.


Articles
#


NOTE:
 Original articles and content published on this site will be linked here, if and when someone writes something for us.

docs.text:
Purpose
#


"Intel" items should be centered around the art and science of applying intelligence techniques to the cyber landscape.  Cyber threat intelligence. There, I said it.


Links
#


Open Source Intelligence Techniques


Synopsis:
 One of the best OSINT resources on the internet.  Tons of useful links and tools.


Articles
#


NOTE:
 Original articles and content published on this site will be linked here, if and when someone writes something for us.

docs.text:
Purpose
#


"How To" articles should highlight a process from end to end.  These should be thoroughly fleshed out, not just break/fix or Stack Overflow links.


Links
#


Securing Nginx with Let's Encrypt on CentOS 7


Synopsis:
 A full walkthrough of setting up TLS on CentOS 7 using nginx and Let's Encrypt.


Articles
#


NOTE:
 Original articles and content published on this site will be linked here, if and when someone writes something for us.

docs.text:
Purpose
#


"References" is primarily for more generic IT-related topics, but is also the catch-all for things that don't fit in another bucket.


Links
#


meirwah/awesome-incident-response


Synopsis:
 A curated list of tools for incident response 


The Children's Illustrated Guide to Kubernetes


Synopsis:
 A tongue-in-cheek guide to Kubernetes, told in the style of a childrens book.


Articles
#


NOTE:
 Original articles and content published on this site will be linked here, if and when someone writes something for us.

Purpose
#


"Exercises" can pertain to anything that provides a guided, or pre-built scenario that you can use to practice cyber-related skills.


Links
#


Malware Traffic Analysis


Synopsis:
 Frequently posts PCAPs and mini-exercises centered around network traffic analysis.

#


"Red Team" resources is the landing place for all things of a more offensive nature.  Offense informs defense, and vice versa.

 Great resource for discovering new tools, primarily offensive, but there's some defense mixed in there too.

docs.text:
Cyber Reference Wiki Style Guide
#


This is where a styleguide should go.  In the meantime, it's markdown examples.


Notes and Warnings
#


NOTE:
 Notes and Warnings are for key information or critical "you'll shoot your eye out" warnings. Use them sparingly.


This code:   


!!! note
    This is a note

!!! warning
    This is a warning





Creates:




Note


This is a note






Warning


This is a warning




Code Blocks
#


This code:


 
``
`


#!/usr/bin/env python



import
 
bacon



print
 
Mmmmm. Bacon.

 
``
`






Creates:


1
2
3
4
5
#!/usr/bin/env python



import
 
bacon



print
 
Mmmmm. Bacon.
docs.title: Style Guide

docs.text: This is where a styleguide should go.  In the meantime, it's markdown examples.
docs.title: Cyber Reference Wiki Style Guide

docs.text:
NOTE:  Notes and Warnings are for key information or critical "you'll shoot your eye out" warnings. Use them sparingly.  This code:     !!! note
    This is a note

!!! warning
    This is a warning  Creates:   Note  This is a note    Warning  This is a warning
docs.title: Notes and Warnings

docs.text:
This code:    `` `  #!/usr/bin/env python  import   bacon  print   Mmmmm. Bacon. 
  `` `   Creates:  1
2
3
4
5 #!/usr/bin/env python  import   bacon  print   Mmmmm. Bacon.
docs.title: Code Blocks
